questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Over the past 6 months, he has had an increase in the frequency of bowel movements and occasional bloody stools. He has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His medications are aspirin, lisinopril, and salmeterol. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. Digital rectal examination shows a large internal hemorrhoid. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rubber band ligation is a treatment option for grade I–III internal hemorrhoids unresponsive to conservative treatment. This patient appears to have a grade I internal hemorrhoid (no history of prolapse), which could explain the blood in his stool. However, it does not explain the change in bowel habits. Additionally, rubber band ligation is not indicated at this time because conservative treatment options have not yet been attempted.

B) INCORRECT:

Dietary counseling (e.g., increased fiber intake) is frequently recommended for patients with hemorrhoids and symptoms related to bowel habits. However, the presence of hematochezia combined with changes in stool habits in an older man should raise suspicion of an underlying disease that requires investigation before dietary counseling is prescribed.

C) CORRECT:

Colonoscopy is the gold standard diagnostic test for colorectal cancer because it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of polyps and suspicious lesions. Given this patient's age (> 65 years), history of smoking, and recent change in stool habits with hematochezia, colorectal cancer is the most concerning diagnosis and must be ruled out.

Although internal hemorrhoid does not take priority over diagnosing and treating colorectal cancer, it does merit intervention in this patient to prevent progression and because it could be contributing to his hematochezia. As it appears to be a grade I internal hemorrhoid (no history of prolapse; see “Grading of internal hemorrhoids” table), conservative therapy (e.g., stool softeners, dietary counseling) is likely necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Stool softeners can be used to decrease discomfort and bleeding from defecation in patients with internal hemorrhoids. However, this patient's symptoms point to an underlying cause that requires testing before he is prescribed symptomatic treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhoidectomy is the treatment of choice for symptomatic grade III and IV internal hemorrhoids or for internal or external hemorrhoids if conservative management has failed. This patient appears to have a grade I internal hemorrhoid (no history of prolapse) for which treatment has not yet been attempted. In addition, while this patient's internal hemorrhoid could explain the blood in his stool, it does not explain his change in bowel habits.
questions.hint: Changes in bowel habits and hematochezia in an older man with a history of smoking should raise suspicion for a specific condition.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 7.2-kg (16-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. For the last 4 weeks, she has also had intermittent constipation and bloating. Four months ago, she spent 2 weeks in Mexico with her daughter. She has never smoked. She drinks one glass of wine daily. She appears thin. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 136/78 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is distended and the liver is palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin with a hard, mildly tender nodule in the left lobe. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Serum studies show:


Alkaline phosphatase
101 U/L


AST
65 U/L


ALT
68 U/L


Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


Hepatitis C antibody
negative


A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Echinococcus granulosus is endemic in Mexico. This patient's travel history to Mexico is a risk factor for the development of a hepatic echinococcal cyst (hydatid cyst) and the infection may be asymptomatic for months, presenting with tender hepatomegaly when large enough. However, echinococcal cysts do not cause constipation, fever, or weight loss. A hepatic echinococcal cyst is seen on contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) as a hypodense cyst with multiple septations and individual "daughter cysts” within the main cyst. The septations give the cyst a characteristic spoke wheel pattern. This patient's history and CECT with multiple, solid, nonseptate lesions that have a peripheral rim enhancement suggest another diagnosis.
Image Description:

Transverse CT abdomen

A single hypodense septated cyst in the right lobe of the liver (red overlay) can be seen. The cyst is most likely due to Echinococcus granulosus.

L: liver; S: stomach; V: vertebra; A: aorta; K: kidney; Sp: spleen

B) INCORRECT:

A liver hemangioma, when symptomatic, causes upper gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, early satiety) in contrast to this patient's primarily lower gastrointestinal symptoms (intermittent constipation with abdominal distention). Furthermore, liver hemangiomas do not cause weight loss or blood in the stool. On contrast-enhanced CT scan, liver hemangioma can also appear as a hypodense lesion with peripheral rim enhancement but are usually solitary.

C) INCORRECT:

Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas (IHC) may manifest with weight loss and hepatomegaly in the absence of cholestasis (jaundice, pruritus). On contrast-enhanced CT scan, a mass-forming IHC is seen as a hypodense lesion with peripheral rim enhancement. However, IHCs are usually solitary, the center of the lesion shows heterogenic echogenicity (compared to the anechoic centers in this patient) and dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. IHCs do not cause constipation or occult blood in stool, and ALP is usually elevated in IHC but is normal in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) may manifest with weight loss, abdominal distention, and deranged liver function tests. However, HCC does not cause lower gastrointestinal symptoms or occult blood in stool. On contrast-enhanced CT scan, HCC appears as a solitary hepatic lesion that characteristically enhances brightly in the arterial phase and appears hypodense in the venous phase due to the rapid contrast washout. Although this patient's CT scan also shows hypodense lesions, the presence of multiple lesions and only minimal rim enhancement in the arterial phase makes HCC an unlikely diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with weight loss, low-grade fever, lower gastrointestinal complaints (i.e., constipation), and evidence of blood in stool (positive stool occult blood test). This contrast-enhanced CT scan shows multiple hypodense solitary lesions with peripheral rim enhancement in both lobes of the liver, characteristic of hepatic metastases. These features are highly suggestive of a primary colorectal malignancy that has metastasized to the liver, the most frequent metastatic site for this condition. The palpable hepatomegaly with a hard nodule and mildly deranged liver function tests are caused by the metastatic deposits.

F) INCORRECT:

Daily consumption of alcohol is a risk factor for the development of cirrhosis. Compensated cirrhotic patients may present with nonspecific symptoms (fatigue, weight loss) in the absence of jaundice, ascites, or variceal bleed. Also, mild derangement of liver function tests may be present. Evidence of occult blood in stool may occur in cirrhosis in the case of a minor gastrointestinal bleed (secondary to esophageal/gastric varices). However, a contrast-enhanced CT scan would show multiple regenerative isoechoic nodules of the hepatic parenchyma in cirrhosis unlike the multiple hypodense solid lesions with anechoic center and peripheral rim enhancement seen in this patient's scan.

G) INCORRECT:

A liver abscess may also manifest with fever, blood in stool, tender hepatomegaly, and mild derangement of liver function tests. However, patients with a pyogenic liver abscess would have features of sepsis (tachycardia, tachypnea) and often, a history of intra-abdominal infection (diarrhea, cholangitis, appendicitis). Mexico is endemic for Entamoeba histolytica and this patient's recent travel history may suggest that she contracted an amebic liver abscess. But most amebic liver abscesses are solitary and this patient's history of weight loss precedes her trip to Mexico. A liver abscess is usually seen on contrast-enhanced CT scan as a solitary, well-defined, fluid-filled hypodense lesion with surrounding hyperemic hepatic parenchyma, unlike the solid lesions seen here.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is concerning for the third most common cancer overall.

questions.text: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. Histopathologic examination of the tumor shows a mucinous, poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Germline mutations in the MLH1 gene result in defective DNA mismatch repair, the underlying cause of Lynch syndrome, which is the most common hereditary form of colorectal cancer. Patients with Lynch syndrome most often have right-sided colon cancers that are diagnosed at a relatively young age (< 50 years old). It is also associated with gastric and endometrial cancer (as seen in this patient's family), as well as ovarian cancer and urothelial cancer. Screening colonoscopy may show a limited number of polyps (usually < 10) or poorly-differentiated tumor growth, as seen in this patient. Other DNA mismatch repair genes include MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

Patients with Lynch syndrome should undergo aggressive screening, which includes annual colonoscopy, pelvic examination for women, and upper endoscopy starting at an early age.
Image Description:

Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the TP53 gene, which encodes p53, is the underlying defect that causes Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Affected patients typically develop sarcomas, breast carcinoma, leukemia, and/or adrenocortical carcinoma. Mutation of the TP53 gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of Lynch syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the DCC gene is responsible for the development of colon cancer. However, it is not linked to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the KRAS gene is linked to the development of colon, lung, and pancreatic cancer, not to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the APC gene causes familial adenomatous polyposis. Affected patients have hundreds of colonic polyps that develop in childhood. These can develop into colorectal cancer, often at an early age. However, FAP does not predispose to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which is more commonly seen in patients with Lynch syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's family fulfills the 3-2-1 rule of Lynch syndrome: cancer in 3 affected family members, within 2 generations, and in 1 relative under 50 years of age.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and dyspnea on exertion for 3 months. During this time, he has also had increased straining during defecation and a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss. He has no personal or family history of serious medical illness. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show microcytic anemia. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows an exophytic mass in the ascending colon. Pathologic examination of the mass shows a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A gain-of-function mutation in which of the following genes is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) in the tumor suppressor gene Deleted in Colon Cancer (DCC) is a late event in the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence) and promotes malignant transformation of an adenoma to a carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

A loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) in the tumor suppressor gene TP53 is a late event in the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence) and promotes malignant transformation of an adenoma to a carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

The microsatellite instability pathway is characterized by a loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) or epigenetic silencing (i.e., promoter hypermethylation) of mismatch repair genes, including MLH1, and can result in the development of colorectal carcinoma. This mechanism underlies Lynch syndrome. However, it is an uncommon cause of sporadic cases of colorectal carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

A loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) of the tumor suppressor gene APC is the initiating event in the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence). This loss-of-function mutation results in decreased intercellular adhesion and increased epithelial proliferation in the colon. Loss-of-function mutations in APC also underlie familial adenomatous polyposis, an inherited syndrome that predisposes to colorectal cancer formation.

E) CORRECT:

Most sporadic cases of colorectal carcinoma arise from the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence). In this pathway, a loss-of-function mutation of the tumor suppressor gene APC results in decreased intercellular adhesion and increased epithelial proliferation. Next, a gain-of-function mutation in the KRAS proto-oncogene results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, which predisposes to adenoma formation. Finally, loss-of-function mutations of additional tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53, DCC) results in malignant transformation of an adenoma to a carcinoma.

Gain-of-function mutations in KRAS are also associated with lung cancer and pancreatic cancer.
Image Description:

Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.
questions.hint: This patient has iron deficiency anemia (progressive fatigue, dyspnea, conjunctival pallor, microcytic anemia, positive stool occult blood) secondary to a well-differentiated, sporadic, right-sided colorectal carcinoma. Most sporadic cases of colorectal carcinoma progress from adenoma to carcinoma due to chromosomal instability.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of dizziness, fatigue, and shortness of breath. He has noticed increased straining with bowel movements and decreased caliber of his stools over the past 3 months. He has no history of medical illness and takes no medications. He appears pale. Physical examination shows mild tachycardia and conjunctival pallor. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 6.4 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 74 μm3. A double-contrast barium enema study in this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Thumbprint sign of the transverse colon
Lead pipe sign of the descending colon
Protruding mass in the proximal ileum
Filling defect of the rectosigmoid colon
String sign in the terminal ileum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thumbprint sign is caused by bowel wall thickening and associated with several conditions, including ischemic colitis and inflammatory bowel disease. These conditions typically cause abdominal pain and diarrhea, which this patient does not have. Moreover, ischemic colitis does not cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber). Patients with recurrent exacerbations of Crohn disease can develop obstructive symptoms due to stricture formation, but the development of these complications in a patient with no prior history of Crohn disease exacerbations is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Lead pipe sign on double-contrast barium enema is a characteristic finding in patients with ulcerative colitis. This condition can develop in older adults and cause iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding. However, this patient lacks classic manifestations of ulcerative colitis such as bloody diarrhea with mucus, abdominal pain, and tenesmus. Moreover, this condition does not typically cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber).

C) INCORRECT:

Diverticular disease, which typically arises in the sigmoid colon, commonly affects older adults. Diverticulosis can cause iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding, and patients with recurrent diverticulitis can develop obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber) due to inflammatory stenosis and subsequent stricture formation. However, this patient has no history of diverticulitis, which typically manifests with fever, left lower quadrant pain, and leukocytosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A protruding mass in the proximal ileum raises concern for small bowel cancer, which can cause a positive fecal occult blood test and iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding. However, small bowel cancer does not typically cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber).

E) CORRECT:

The rectosigmoid colon is the most commonly involved site of colorectal carcinoma, followed by the ascending colon and then the descending colon. Lumen constriction caused by circumferential tumor growth results in a characteristic apple core lesion filling defect on double-contrast barium enema study. Colorectal carcinoma should be suspected as an underlying cause of iron deficiency anemia in men > 50 years of age and postmenopausal women. Left-sided colorectal carcinomas, which involve the rectosigmoid colon and/or the descending colon, are more likely to cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber) than right-sided colorectal carcinomas, which involve the ascending colon.
Image Description:

Fluoroscopy (barium enema; lateral view)

An apple core sign (also called napkin ring sign; green overlay) is seen in the distal descending colon. It is the result of annular constriction by a colorectal carcinoma.

F) INCORRECT:

A string sign in the distal ileum (which can be seen on a barium swallow study, not a double-contrast barium enema study) is a characteristic finding in patients with Crohn disease. This condition can develop in older adults and cause iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding. However, this patient lacks classic manifestations of Crohn disease such as diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients with recurrent exacerbations of Crohn disease can develop obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber) due to stricture formation. However, the development of these complications in a patient with no prior history of Crohn disease exacerbations is unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor, tachycardia, decreased mean corpuscular volume) and a positive fecal occult blood test, most likely due to underlying colorectal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of intermittent fever, abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and sensation of incomplete rectal emptying. He also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness. Colonoscopy shows circumferential erythematous lesions that extend without interruption from the anal verge to the cecum. A biopsy specimen taken from the rectum shows mucosal and submucosal inflammation with crypt abscesses. This patient is most likely at risk of developing colon cancer with which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sporadic colorectal carcinomas are commonly unifocal. Ulcerative colitis, however, is more likely to be associated with multifocal lesions, due to the underlying diffuse pattern of chronic mucosal and submucosal inflammation. These multifocal lesions are likely to induce a widespread field change effect within the colon that increases the chance of neoplasia in more than one focus.

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of heterozygosity of the p53 tumor suppressor is associated with the development of several different types of neoplastic lesions, including sporadic colorectal carcinomas (CRC). In sporadic CRC, p53 mutation occurs late in the course of the disease, leading to the adenoma to carcinoma sequence. However, in patients with inflammatory bowel disease, the development of colorectal carcinoma is characterized by early p53 mutation.

C) CORRECT:

Recurrent cycles of inflammation, which are a common feature of UC, result in the release of inflammatory mediators that initially promote cellular hyperplasia and, ultimately, non-polypoid dysplasia. Although reversible, dysplasia can progress to neoplasia and is the most likely cause of development of colorectal carcinoma in patients with chronic inflammatory bowel diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-grade lesions of the colon are typically well circumscribed and have an intact capsule; examples include hamartomatous, mucosal, and submucosal colonic polyps. Cancer that arises secondary to ulcerative colitis is more likely to result from chronic and extensive inflammation and is more typically characterized by a high-grade rather than low-grade lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Early APC tumor suppressor gene mutation is thought to be the inciting event in the pathogenesis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and sporadic colorectal carcinomas. However, in patients with IBD, this mutation is uncommon and when present, usually occurs late in the course of the disease process.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms and colonoscopy findings suggest ulcerative colitis (UC).

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years during her twenties. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum lipid studies and glucose concentration are within the reference ranges. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends screening women ≥ 65 years of age for osteoporosis using bone measurement testing (e.g., DEXA scan or quantitative ultrasonography). Women < 65 years of age should be screened if they have a moderately increased risk for osteoporosis according to clinical tools, such as the Fracture Risk Assessment Tool. This patient does not have significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., personal or parental history of hip fracture, chronic glucocorticoid use, significant alcohol consumption, current smoking).

B) CORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends screening all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age for colorectal cancer (the previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years). Screening strategies include annual fecal immunochemical testing, flexible sigmoidoscopy or CT colonography every 5 years, and colonoscopy screening every 10 years. Over 90% of cases of colorectal cancer occur in adults ≥ 45 years of age, and there is significant evidence that early detection decreases mortality.

Individuals with a first-degree relative with colorectal cancer or advanced adenoma diagnosed at < 60 years of age should start screening with complete colonoscopy at age 40 or 10 years earlier than the index patient's age at diagnosis; whichever is earlier.

C) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF has concluded that routine ECG screenings do not decrease the risk of myocardial infarction or stroke. Current evidence regarding routine ECG screening for atrial fibrillation is also insufficient to recommend this test.

D) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF has concluded that there is insufficient evidence to support routine thyroid function screening in nonpregnant patients. Pregnancy (particularly during the first trimester) can interfere with normal circulating levels of TSH. Women who are planning pregnancy and are at increased risk for thyroid disorders (e.g., family history of autoimmune thyroid disease, presence of a goiter) can be screened, but universal screening is not generally recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends genetic counseling and potential genetic testing for BRCA mutations for women who have a positive result on a familial risk assessment tool that assesses risk for BRCA-related cancers (e.g., breast, ovarian, tubal, and peritoneal cancer). This patient has no such family history.

F) INCORRECT:

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening with abdominal ultrasonography can be considered in individuals < 65 years of age who have multiple risk factors for AAA or a family history of AAA, neither of which applies to this patient.
questions.hint: This screening test is recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) for asymptomatic individuals ≥ 45 years of age.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of blood in his stool for the past week. He has lost 7.7 kg (17 lb) of weight and has been passing hard, small, thin stools for the past 2 months. He was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 20 years ago and he has responded well to treatment. His mother also has ulcerative colitis. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His only medication is mesalamine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows slight conjunctival pallor. There is mild tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant. Rectal examination shows no abnormalities. A barium enema is shown. A CT scan of the abdomen, pelvis, and chest shows no other enlarged lymph nodes or focal lesions. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left hemicolectomy is indicated in patients with a tumor in the descending colon, which this patient most likely has. However, this patient also has ulcerative colitis, and removing half of the colon does not reduce the risk of developing additional malignancies in the remaining colon. Therefore, another treatment option is more appropriate.
Image Description:

Extent of resection (left): between the distal third of the transverse colon and sigmoid colon (blue dashed lines). The arterial blood supply to this section, including the inferior mesenteric artery and the left branch of the middle colic artery, is ligated (purple dashed lines). Malignancy (lesions shown in gray) is a common indication for this procedure.

Reconstruction (right): typically achieved via end-to-end colorectal anastomosis

B) INCORRECT:

Neoadjuvant radiation therapy (NART) is indicated in patients with locally advanced rectal carcinoma. However, in colon cancer, radiation therapy is not a standard therapeutic modality.

C) INCORRECT:

Budesonide enema is used in the treatment of mild to moderate ulcerative colitis (UC) if the response to 5-ASA (e.g., mesalamine) is not sufficient. Although bloody bowel movements, weight loss, and anemia may be symptoms of a UC flare in this patient treated with mesalamine, other symptoms such as diarrhea, fecal urgency, abdominal pain, and tenesmus are absent. This patient most likely has colon cancer, for which budesonide enema is not an appropriate treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Osmotic laxatives such as polyethylene glycol (PEG) can be used in the treatment of constipation. However, the underlying cause of this patient's constipation is most likely colon cancer, which requires a different treatment at this time.

E) CORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a risk factor for developing colorectal cancer and the risk increases with increased duration and/or extent of disease. This patient's features (i.e., blood in stool, unintentional weight loss, change in stool consistency, anemia) in conjunction with the results of his barium enema are consistent with malignant transformation. The CT scan suggests no lymph node involvement and no metastases. As UC is restricted to the colon and rectum, a proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis or ileostomy is a potentially curative treatment for both UC and colorectal carcinoma.
questions.hint: On the barium enema, an apple core sign (also called napkin ring sign) is seen in the distal descending colon, which suggests annular constriction due to colorectal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent diarrhea and blood-streaked stools. He has also had progressive fatigue for the past 3 months. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. His pulse is 105/min and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.2 g/dL. Colonoscopy shows a 4-cm ulcerated mass in the descending colon. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely involved in the development of this patient’s endoscopic findings?

choices.text: Mutation in E-cadherin of enterochromaffin cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mutation in E-cadherin of enterochromaffin cells is seen in carcinoid syndrome, which can manifest with diarrhea, fatigue, and anemia. However, carcinoid syndrome typically also manifests with abdominal cramping, cutaneous flushing, palpitations, and dyspnea, none of which is seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Amplification of the L-myc oncogene is associated with small-cell lung cancer, not colorectal cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Dysregulated Th2 cell-mediated response is seen in ulcerative colitis, which can manifest with diarrhea, blood-streaked stools, fatigue, and anemia. However, colonoscopy typically shows mucosal/submucosal inflammation, friable mucosa, deep ulcerations, loss of haustra, and/or pseudopolyps. A discrete 4-cm ulcerated mass would not be expected.

D) CORRECT:

Overexpression of cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) is associated with the development of colorectal adenocarcinomas. The overexpression of COX-2 promotes angiogenesis by stimulating vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), which contributes to the tumorigenesis of colorectal cancer. Long-term use of medications that block COX-2 (e.g., aspirin, ibuprofen, naproxen) is thought to have a chemoprotective effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Hereditary mutation in MLH1 gene is one of four DNA mismatch repair gene mutations seen in Lynch syndrome that causes microsatellite instability, which leads to the development of early-onset colorectal cancer. However, affected individuals typically develop a small number of adenomas that can rapidly progress to colorectal cancer, resulting in a considerably earlier symptom onset compared to that in sporadic colorectal cancer. In addition, this patient has no family history of colorectal cancer.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of blood-streaked stools, progressive fatigue, anemia, and a 4-cm ulcerated mass in the descending colon suggests a diagnosis of colorectal cancer.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents for a routine physical examination and asks when he should start screening for colorectal cancer. He is eager to start as early as possible because he now has a family history: his mother recently had a stage I colon cancer resected at age 65. He has no abdominal pain, weight loss, or rectal bleeding.
Which one of the following colorectal cancer screening options should be offered to this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

People who have a first-degree relative with either colorectal cancer or an advanced adenoma (i.e., an adenoma ≥ 1 cm or with high-grade dysplasia or villous features) are at increased risk for colorectal cancer, regardless of the age at which the relative was diagnosed. Joint guidelines from the American College of Gastroenterology and the American Gastroenterological Association recommend that these individuals initiate colorectal cancer screening at an earlier age than average-risk patients.

The latest recommendations are as follows:

• The recommended age at which to initiate colorectal cancer screening in average-risk individuals depends on the specific guidelines being followed. Historically, most guidelines have recommended starting screening at age 50, but increasingly, guidelines recommend starting at age 45 because of the rising incidence of colorectal cancer in younger populations.
• First-degree relatives of patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer or an advanced adenoma before age 60 should initiate screening colonoscopy at either age 40 or 10 years before the age at which the index case was diagnosed, whichever comes first.
• If the relative was diagnosed with colorectal cancer or an advanced adenoma after age 60, then colorectal cancer screening with colonoscopy can be offered as early as age 40 if this is the patient’s preference, although starting screening at the same age as average-risk individuals would also be acceptable.

Key learning point: First-degree relatives of individuals diagnosed with colorectal cancer after age 60 can be offered colorectal cancer screening with colonoscopy as early as age 40 and no later than age 50.

B) INCORRECT:

Although flexible sigmoidoscopy and fecal occult-blood (or fecal immunochemical) testing are acceptable alternative screening methods for people who are unwilling to undergo colonoscopy, colonoscopy is strongly recommended for patients at above-average risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Although flexible sigmoidoscopy and fecal occult-blood (or fecal immunochemical) testing are acceptable alternative screening methods for people who are unwilling to undergo colonoscopy, colonoscopy is strongly recommended for patients at above-average risk.

D) INCORRECT:

A 39-year-old man was admitted for a bowel obstruction and found to have a large obstructing colonic adenocarcinoma just proximal to the hepatic flexure. He underwent a successful right hemicolectomy. Pathology was consistent with an obstructing, 9-cm colon adenocarcinoma, with no evidence of lymph node involvement in 17 sampled nodes.
When asked about his family history, the patient states that his mother and maternal aunt were diagnosed with endometrial cancer at ages 56 and 59, respectively. His mother has no other siblings, but her father died in his early 40s of an unknown cause after several months of worsening abdominal pain and weight loss. The patient has two younger siblings and three children, all of whom are healthy.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by the development of gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps; the development of small, dark-colored spots on the lips, around and inside the mouth, near the eyes and nostrils, and around the anus; and an increased risk for cancers of the gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, cervix, ovary, and breast.

B) INCORRECT:

BRCA mutations are associated with premature breast and ovarian cancers and, to a lesser extent, pancreatic and prostate cancers.

C) CORRECT:

There are two principal inherited colorectal cancer syndromes: familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; also known as Lynch syndrome). This patient’s history of a large right-sided colon cancer, in combination with his family history of endometrial cancer, strongly suggests HNPCC.

Compared with FAP, HNPCC usually causes larger, less-aggressive right-sided colon cancers. When systemic treatment is needed, HNPCC colon tumors are thought to be more responsive to chemotherapy than FAP tumors. HNPCC also causes endometrial cancer and, to a lesser extent, cancers of the ovary, stomach, small bowel, pancreas, hepatobiliary tract, brain, and upper uroepithelial tract.

Key learning point: Other than colorectal cancer, the most common cancer associated with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome) is endometrial cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Li-Fraumeni syndrome is associated with breast cancer, sarcoma, brain tumors, and leukemia.

E) INCORRECT:

FAP tends to cause aggressive distal colonic lesions in a background of colonic polyposis and also predisposes patients to duodenal polyps, gastric cancer, and abdominal desmoid tumors.

On rectal examination, the patient has normal sphincter tone; the edge of a rubbery, hard but mobile mass is palpated approximately 6 cm from the anus. Bedside stool examination reveals brown, heme-positive stool. Office-based anoscopy reveals a lesion in the rectum (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of the carcinoembryonic antigen level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sucralfate enemas have been used with some success to manage the symptoms of radiation proctitis, but they have no role in managing the symptoms of colorectal cancer.

Barium enema may be useful in evaluating hematochezia and other symptoms of colon cancer, but it is less sensitive than colonoscopy and would not allow for tissue diagnosis of the lesion that has already been identified.

C) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels have no role in this patient’s management at this time. After a diagnosis has been made, CEA levels can be used, along with imaging, for pretreatment staging. These levels are also tracked after colorectal cancer resection, as increases may indicate disease recurrence.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy would allow for further evaluation and biopsy of this lesion, but before any curative surgical intervention can occur, the entire colon must be evaluated to rule out any synchronous colorectal polyps or cancers that could necessitate a more extensive colon resection.

This patient’s hematochezia and change in stool caliber are concerning for colorectal cancer, and the fungating lesion evident on anoscopy is suggestive of rectal adenocarcinoma. Colonoscopy is the most appropriate next step in evaluation, as it will allow for more thorough examination of the lesion, biopsy for confirmatory tissue diagnosis, and evaluation of possible synchronous lesions (independent, second sites of colorectal cancer). Such lesions occur in 3% to 5% of patients with colorectal cancer and should be ruled out before curative resection of the rectal lesion is considered.

Key learning point: In a patient with a suspected rectal adenocarcinoma, the most appropriate first step in evaluation is colonoscopy, to biopsy the lesion and rule out synchronous lesions before surgical resection is considered.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. Over the past 6 months, he has had an increase in the frequency of bowel movements, occasional bloody stools, and fatigue. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an internal hemorrhoid. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Laboratory studies show microcytic anemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT scan evaluates intra-abdominal structures and stages malignancies but has limited sensitivity for colonic mucosal lesions. It does not allow for biopsy, which is essential for diagnosing bleeding lesions in the gastrointestinal tract. CT is more suited for assessing disease extent after lesion identification, not as a primary diagnostic tool for suspected colorectal cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy visualizes only the rectum and sigmoid colon, missing proximal lesions. In older patients with positive fecal occult blood tests, microcytic anemia, and changes in bowel habits, potential bleeding sources may lie beyond the distal colon.

C) CORRECT:

Colonoscopy is the gold standard diagnostic test for colorectal cancer because it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of polyps and suspicious lesions. Given this patient's age (> 65 years), history of smoking, anemia, and recent change in stool habits with hematochezia, colorectal cancer is the most concerning diagnosis and must be ruled out.

Although internal hemorrhoid does not take priority over diagnosing and treating colorectal cancer, it does merit intervention in this patient to prevent progression and because it could be contributing to his hematochezia.

Key learning point: Colonoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing suspected colorectal cancer, as it enables direct visualization and biopsy of lesions throughout the entire colon.

D) INCORRECT:

Barium enema outlines the colon using contrast but lacks direct mucosal visualization, reducing sensitivity for small or flat lesions. It cannot obtain tissue samples, limiting its utility for histological diagnosis in patients with suspected colorectal cancer.

Dietary counseling (e.g., increased fiber intake) is frequently recommended for patients with hemorrhoids and symptoms related to bowel habits. However, the presence of hematochezia combined with changes in stool habits and anemia in an older man should raise suspicion of an underlying disease that requires investigation before dietary counseling is prescribed.
questions.hint: Changes in bowel habits, hematochezia, and features of iron deficiency anemia (microcytosis, fatigue) in an older man with a history of smoking should raise suspicion for underlying malignancy.

A 72-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, a 4.5-kg weight loss over six months, and intermittent abdominal discomfort. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history and occasionally uses NSAIDs for joint pain. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, and abdominal examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show microcytic anemia, and a fecal occult blood test is positive. No prior colonoscopy is documented.
What is the most appropriate next step to confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Barium enema outlines the colon using contrast but lacks direct mucosal visualization, reducing sensitivity for small or flat lesions. It cannot obtain tissue samples, limiting its utility for histological diagnosis in patients with weight loss, microcytic anemia, and positive fecal occult blood test. Direct inspection and biopsy are necessary, which barium enema does not provide.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT scan evaluates intra-abdominal structures and stages malignancies but has limited sensitivity for colonic mucosal lesions. It does not allow for biopsy, which is essential for diagnosing bleeding lesions in the gastrointestinal tract. CT is more suited for assessing disease extent after lesion identification, not as a primary diagnostic tool for chronic bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy visualizes only the rectum and sigmoid colon, missing proximal lesions. In older patients with positive fecal occult blood tests, weight loss, and anemia, potential bleeding sources may lie beyond the distal colon. Its limited scope makes it inadequate for confirming diagnoses when broader colonic pathology is suspected.

D) CORRECT:

Colonoscopy provides full visualization of the colon, allowing for detection of lesions, polyps, or masses responsible for occult bleeding and anemia. It enables biopsy for histopathological confirmation, crucial for diagnosing colorectal cancer. The patient's weight loss, microcytic anemia, and positive fecal occult blood test necessitate direct examination of the colonic mucosa. Colonoscopy aligns with guidelines for comprehensive evaluation and early detection of neoplastic changes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of dizziness, fatigue, and shortness of breath. He reports increased straining with bowel movements and decreased caliber of his stools over the past 3 months. He has no known medical conditions and takes no medications. On examination, he appears pale, has mild tachycardia, and conjunctival pallor. Stool testing for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 64 g/L (125–170) and mean corpuscular volume is 74 fL (80–100). Which one of the following is most likely to be seen on a double-contrast barium enema study in this patient?

choices.text: String sign in the terminal ileum.
Thumbprint sign of the transverse colon.
Filling defect of the rectosigmoid colon.
Lead pipe sign of the descending colon.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A string sign in the distal ileum on a barium swallow is a characteristic finding in patients with Crohn disease. Although Crohn disease can lead to iron-deficiency anemia from chronic bleeding, this patient lacks classic manifestations of this condition, such as diarrhea and abdominal pain. Recurrent Crohn flares may cause stricture formation and obstructive signs (e.g., straining during defecation or a narrowed stool caliber), but such complications are unlikely without a history of prior exacerbations.

B) INCORRECT:

Thumbprint sign reflects bowel wall thickening and is seen in conditions such as ischemic colitis and inflammatory bowel disease, which typically manifest with abdominal pain and diarrhea. In patients with recurrent Crohn disease flares or chronic ischemic colitis, stricture formation can lead to obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, narrowed stool caliber), but this complication is unlikely without a prior history of Crohn’s exacerbations or ischemic colitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Diverticular disease, which typically arises in the sigmoid colon, can lead to iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding. Recurrent diverticulitis can cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber) due to inflammatory stenosis and subsequent stricture formation. However, this patient has no history of diverticulitis, which typically manifests with fever and left lower quadrant pain.

D) CORRECT:

The rectosigmoid colon is the most commonly involved site of colorectal carcinoma, followed by the ascending colon and then the descending colon. Lumen constriction caused by circumferential tumor growth results in a characteristic apple core lesion filling defect on double-contrast barium enema study. Colorectal carcinoma should be suspected as an underlying cause of iron deficiency anemia in men > 50 years of age and postmenopausal women. Left-sided colorectal carcinomas, which involve the rectosigmoid colon and/or the descending colon, are more likely to cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber) than right-sided colorectal carcinomas, which involve the ascending colon.

Key learning point: An apple core filling defect on barium enema is characteristic of colorectal carcinoma, which commonly causes iron deficiency anemia and obstructive symptoms in older adults.

An apple core sign (also called napkin ring sign; green overlay) is seen in the distal descending colon. It is the result of annular constriction by a colorectal carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Lead pipe sign on double-contrast barium enema is a characteristic finding in patients with ulcerative colitis. This condition can cause iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding. However, this patient lacks classic manifestations of ulcerative colitis, such as bloody diarrhea with mucus, abdominal pain, and tenesmus. Moreover, this condition does not typically cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber).
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor, tachycardia, decreased mean corpuscular volume) and a positive fecal occult blood test, most likely due to underlying colorectal carcinoma.

She has no personal or family history of serious illness, and underwent a mammography one year ago. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years in her twenties. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical examination is normal. Serum lipid studies and glucose concentration are within reference ranges. Which one of the following screening studies is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC recommends a screening mammography every 2–3 years for average-risk women aged 50–74, but current guidelines recommend against offering BRCA1/2 testing routinely to average-risk women. The SOGC recommends genetic counselling and potential BRCA1/2 testing for women who meet established familial or clinical high-risk criteria (e.g., early-onset breast, ovarian, or male breast cancer); this patient has no such family history.

B) INCORRECT:

Routine thyroid‐stimulating hormone screening in asymptomatic nonpregnant adults is not recommended. Pregnancy (particularly during the first trimester) can interfere with normal circulating levels of TSH. Women who are planning pregnancy and are at increased risk for thyroid disorders (e.g., family history of autoimmune thyroid disease, presence of a goiter) can be screened, but universal screening is not generally recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC advises beginning with a FRAX assessment in women ≥ 65 years of age and proceeding to DEXA only if pharmacotherapy is being considered. The 2023 Osteoporosis Canada guideline recommends DEXA screening for all women ≥ 70 years; for those 65–69 years of age with ≥ 1 significant risk factor (e.g., personal or parental hip fracture, chronic glucocorticoid use, significant alcohol consumption, current smoking); and for women aged 50–64 who have sustained a fragility fracture or have ≥ 2 significant risk factors. Since this 53-year-old patient has no significant risk factors, osteoporosis screening is not indicated at this time.

D) CORRECT:

The 2010 Canadian Association of Gastroenterology (CAG) and 2016 Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care (CTFPHC) guidelines both recommend screening average-risk asymptomatic adults aged 50–75 years for colorectal cancer, as early detection in this group significantly lowers mortality. Recommended methods are biennial fecal tests (e.g., immunochemical or high-sensitivity guaiac occult blood tests) or flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years. Because of long wait times, greater resource demands, and higher risks without clear evidence of superior efficacy, colonoscopy is not recommended for routine screening of average-risk adults, but its use is recommended for follow-up on any positive screening test result. Neither guideline supports routine screening before age 50, though rising early-onset colorectal cancer rates in Canadians under 50 have prompted some experts to suggest beginning at 45. After age 75, the CTFPHC advises against routine screening; the CAG, however, suggests individualized decisions for those aged 76–85.

Key learning point: Colorectal cancer screening with fecal tests or sigmoidoscopy is recommended for average-risk adults starting at age 50 and continuing until age 75.

E) INCORRECT:

He mentions his bowel movements have become more frequent and watery over the past 2 months, occurring 4–5 times daily. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and mild peripheral edema. Vital signs are BP, 145/88; P, 102; oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 7.8 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 68 fL, ferritin 8 ng/mL, and creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (baseline 1.8 mg/dL). What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform digital rectal examination and test for occult blood
Order CT abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
Initiate iron supplementation and nephrology consultation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Digital rectal examination is the most appropriate initial step in the emergency department evaluation of a patient with multiple red flags for colorectal cancer, which include iron deficiency anemia in a man aged over 50 years, altered bowel habits, and progressive symptoms. The examination can identify palpable rectal masses, and occult blood testing confirms gastrointestinal bleeding. This combination of findings in this age group has a strong association with colorectal malignancy and requires immediate evaluation before proceeding to other diagnostic studies.

B) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen has very low sensitivity for detecting colorectal carcinoma and is not an adequate parameter for screening or diagnosis. This tumor marker is used as a prognostic indicator and for monitoring treatment response and recurrence in patients with established colorectal cancer, but it is not used in the initial evaluation of suspected malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

CT imaging may be valuable for staging purposes, but imaging studies are not the initial step in emergency department evaluation of suspected colorectal cancer. Additionally, IV contrast should be used cautiously in this patient with chronic kidney disease and elevated creatinine.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient requires treatment for anemia and may benefit from nephrology consultation for kidney disease management, initiating iron supplementation without investigating the underlying cause of iron deficiency in a male patient > 50 years of age is inappropriate. Iron deficiency anemia in men > 50 years of age requires evaluation for underlying pathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing colorectal cancer but is not typically arranged as an urgent procedure from the emergency department. Endoscopic evaluation is coordinated as an outpatient or inpatient procedure after initial assessment.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of colorectal cancer treated with right hemicolectomy three years ago presents to the ED with progressive abdominal distension, early satiety, and worsening dyspnea. Vital signs are BP, 108/64 mm Hg; P, 104; R, 24; T, 37.4°C (99.3°F). On exam, she has tense ascites, shifting dullness, and bilateral lower extremity edema. Laboratory results are notable for albumin 2.1 g/dL (normal 3.5–5.0), sodium 129 mEq/L (normal 136–145), and potassium 3.6 mEq/L (normal 3.5–5.0). CT abdomen confirms massive ascites without free intraperitoneal air. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While systemic chemotherapy may be indicated in the long-term oncologic management of peritoneal carcinomatosis, it is not the most appropriate next step in management. The patient’s acute problem is symptomatic malignant ascites requiring palliation and stabilization.

B) INCORRECT:

Diuretics may help in cirrhotic ascites but are typically less effective in malignant ascites due to peritoneal carcinomatosis. Relying on diuretics alone does not provide rapid symptomatic relief or address the patient’s acute respiratory compromise.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — This patient has symptomatic malignant ascites likely due to peritoneal carcinomatosis. The most appropriate ED management is therapeutic paracentesis to relieve dyspnea and abdominal pressure. Diagnostic analysis of ascitic fluid should also be performed to exclude concurrent infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy is indicated for bowel perforation, ischemia, or peritonitis. This patient has stable vitals, no peritoneal signs, and imaging consistent with ascites. Emergent surgery is not appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Discharging the patient with outpatient follow-up would not be appropriate given her significant ascites and dyspnea. She requires symptomatic relief and further diagnostic evaluation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of worsening crampy abdominal pain and 2 days of nausea and inability to pass stool or gas. She reports a 3-month history of progressively narrowing stool caliber and occasional blood streaking. Physical examination shows abdominal distention, tympany, and high-pitched bowel sounds. CT imaging shows dilated colon proximal to a transition point in the sigmoid region with wall thickening. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Gastroenterology consultation for colonoscopy with biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids have no role in mechanical bowel obstruction caused by malignancy. This patient requires mechanical relief of the obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Additional contrast studies would delay definitive management and are unnecessary given the clear CT findings of mechanical obstruction. Oral contrast could worsen the obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Enema is inappropriate in complete bowel obstruction and could lead to bowel perforation. This patient's inability to pass stool is due to mechanical obstruction, not simple constipation requiring stool evacuation measures.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with complete large bowel obstruction secondary to suspected colorectal cancer. The clinical presentation of progressive stool caliber changes, blood streaking, and current complete obstruction with CT findings of dilated proximal colon and sigmoid wall thickening strongly suggest malignant obstruction. Immediate management requires nasogastric decompression to prevent aspiration and emergency surgical consultation for definitive management of the obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is contraindicated in complete bowel obstruction due to the increased risk of perforation. The obstruction must be relieved before any endoscopic evaluation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes presents with a 6-week history of intermittent hematochezia and progressive decrease in stool caliber. He reports mild cramping pain and sensation of incomplete evacuation. His hemoglobin is 10.2 g/dL, and his last colonoscopy 8 years ago was normal. Physical examination shows stable vital signs and mild pallor. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treating anemia with iron supplementation without proper evaluation would be inappropriate. The patient has clear red flags for colorectal cancer that require immediate assessment.

B) INCORRECT:

Outpatient colonoscopy within 2 weeks is inappropriate. This patient has multiple red flags for colorectal cancer (hematochezia, decreased stool caliber, unexplained iron deficiency anemia at > 50 years of age) requiring a more urgent evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Digital rectal examination is indicated for all patients with lower gastrointestinal bleeding or red flags for colorectal cancer. This patient has multiple concerning features including hematochezia, decreased stool caliber, tenesmus, and anemia. Digital rectal examination is part of the routine clinical evaluation before proceeding with endoscopic evaluation. Findings may include palpable distal rectal cancers.

D) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) has very low sensitivity for detecting colorectal carcinoma and should not be used for screening or diagnosis. CEA is a prognostic tumor marker used to monitor treatment response and evaluate for recurrence in patients with confirmed colorectal cancer; it is not used for the initial evaluation of suspected disease.

E) INCORRECT:

CT colonography may be useful if colonoscopy cannot be completed, but another step should be performed first as part of the initial clinical evaluation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 6-kg (13-lb) unintentional weight loss of over the past 3 months. He has also noticed intermittent blood mixed with his stools and a change in bowel habits, alternating between constipation and diarrhea. Three years ago, he was treated with eradication therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and celiac disease diagnosed at age 24 years. He follows a strict gluten-free, pescatarian diet. Medications are lisinopril, atorvastatin, and an iron supplement. He drinks one glass of wine every other day. His body mass index is 23 kg/m2. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae and mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin concentration of 10.2 g/dL. Histopathology of a colon biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Heavy alcohol consumption is a modest risk factor for colorectal cancer, especially with chronic use. However, this patient only consumes one glass of wine every other day, which does not meet the threshold for heavy consumption.

B) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease is associated with an increased risk of enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma and small bowel adenocarcinoma but not with colorectal adenocarcinoma. Long-standing, untreated celiac disease can cause malabsorption and nutritional deficiencies, but this patient adheres to a gluten-free diet.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic H. pylori infection is a well-established risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma and MALT lymphoma but has not been linked to colorectal cancer.

D) CORRECT:

Increasing age (> 40 years) is the most significant risk factor for colorectal adenocarcinoma, with peak incidence between 70–80 years of age. Colorectal cancer incidence rises sharply with age, as the accumulation of genetic mutations and epigenetic alterations over time increases the likelihood of malignant transformation in colonic epithelial cells. Other risk factors include a history of adenomatous and serrated polyps, familial cancer syndromes (e.g., hereditary polyposis syndromes), inflammatory bowel disease, tobacco use, a diet of processed meat with low fiber, and heavy alcohol use. However, age remains the single strongest predictor of disease in older individuals without other risk factors. Therefore, screening guidelines prioritize older adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Some studies suggest that a low-fiber diet is a potential risk factor for colorectal cancer, but there is limited evidence to support the association. Furthermore, this patient adheres to a pescatarian diet, which may reduce the risk of colorectal cancer.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows hyperchromatic cells, nuclei with atypical features, desmoplasia, and colonic glands extending into the submucosa, all of which indicate colonic adenocarcinoma. Weight loss, anemia, blood in the stool, and altered bowel habits are classic features of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 3-month history of progressive fatigue. He reports a new onset of constipation and has noticed his stools are narrower than usual. He also reports an unintentional 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. On examination, he has pale conjunctiva. A digital rectal exam is unremarkable, but a fecal occult blood test is positive. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL and a mean corpuscular volume of 76 fL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A double-contrast barium enema is a radiologic study that can identify large colonic masses. However, this test has a lower sensitivity for detecting smaller polyps and flat lesions than the gold standard. Furthermore, it does not permit tissue sampling for diagnosis, which is essential in this patient with a high suspicion of cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

CT colonography is a valid screening modality for colorectal cancer and can detect polyps and masses. However, it is purely an imaging study and does not allow for tissue sampling. In a symptomatic patient with high suspicion for malignancy, proceeding directly to the gold standard test for colorectal cancer is the most appropriate next step.

C) INCORRECT:

A fecal immunochemical test (FIT) is a first-line screening test for colorectal cancer in asymptomatic, average-risk individuals. This patient is symptomatic with multiple alarm features and has a positive fecal occult blood test, indicating gastrointestinal bleeding. A FIT would be redundant and would not provide a definitive diagnosis or guide management.

D) CORRECT:

Complete colonoscopy is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of colorectal cancer because it allows for direct visualization of the entire colonic mucosa to identify any masses, polyps, or other lesions. Critically, it also allows for biopsy of suspicious findings to obtain a definitive histopathologic diagnosis and for therapeutic removal of precancerous polyps. Given the high clinical suspicion, a colonoscopy is the most direct and comprehensive diagnostic test for this patient, superseding screening-level investigations.

E) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the rectum and sigmoid colon. While this patient's symptoms of constipation and narrow stools may suggest a distal lesion, this procedure only evaluates the distal one-third of the colon. It would miss any proximal cancers, which are more commonly associated with iron deficiency anemia, as well as any synchronous polyps.
questions.hint: This patient presents with multiple red flags for colorectal cancer, including a change in bowel habits, weight loss, and evidence of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive fatigue, right upper quadrant discomfort, and an unintentional 7-kg (15 lb) weight loss. He has alternating constipation and diarrhea with occasional dark streaks of blood in his stool, which he attributes to hemorrhoids. His medical history is significant for iron deficiency anemia, managed with oral supplements without a full diagnostic workup. On examination, he has mild scleral icterus. His abdomen is soft with a firm, nodular liver edge palpable 4 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL, alkaline phosphatase of 450 U/L, and total bilirubin of 2.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely primary diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic adenocarcinoma can cause weight loss and jaundice and frequently metastasizes to the liver, which can cause hepatic findings similar to those seen in this patient. However, this diagnosis does not typically cause a change in bowel habits like alternating constipation and diarrhea or hematochezia. Furthermore, while anemia can occur, profound iron deficiency anemia from chronic occult bleeding is much more characteristic of a different primary tumor.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a primary liver malignancy that can manifest with hepatomegaly, constitutional symptoms, and abnormal liver function tests. However, the most common causes of HCC include underlying cirrhosis from chronic viral hepatitis or alcohol use, which is not reported in this patient. Additionally, HCC does not explain the prominent gastrointestinal symptoms (altered bowel habits, blood in the stool, iron deficiency anemia).

C) INCORRECT:

Cholangiocarcinoma, a cancer of the bile ducts, manifests with signs of biliary obstruction, such as jaundice and markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin, which are present in this patient. However, altered bowel habits, hematochezia, and/or chronic iron deficiency anemia resulting from slow gastrointestinal blood loss are not seen in cholangiocarcinoma, making this diagnosis unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's metastatic liver disease is most likely due to a primary colorectal carcinoma (CRC), which manifests with changes in bowel habits, hematochezia, and unexplained iron deficiency anemia in an older male. The liver is the most common site of metastasis from CRC due to venous drainage from the colon directly into the portal circulation. The combination of gastrointestinal symptoms and evidence of hepatic metastases makes CRC the most likely underlying diagnosis. A colonoscopy would be the next diagnostic step to confirm the primary tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Alcoholic cirrhosis can cause hepatomegaly, jaundice, and abnormal liver tests. However, the liver edge is typically firm, in contrast to the nodular appearance seen in this patient, which suggests the presence of discrete masses. Furthermore, cirrhosis is a non-malignant process and does not explain the patient’s significant weight loss or the constellation of lower gastrointestinal symptoms, such as altered bowel habits and hematochezia, which suggest a different etiology.
questions.hint: This patient's signs and symptoms of right upper quadrant discomfort, nodular hepatomegaly, jaundice, and elevated alkaline phosphatase raise suspicion for metastatic liver disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive constipation and fatigue. He reports intermittent, small amounts of bright red blood on the toilet paper. He has unintentionally lost 4.5 kg (10 lb) over the past 6 months. His paternal uncle was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 72. On examination, his abdomen is soft and non-tender. A digital rectal examination is normal, but the stool is guaiac-positive. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL and a mean corpuscular volume of 76 fL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT colonography, or virtual colonoscopy, is a radiologic imaging technique used for colorectal cancer screening. Although it can visualize the entire colon and detect polyps or masses, it does not allow for tissue sampling. If a suspicious lesion is found, the patient would still require a biopsy to establish a diagnosis. Therefore, it is not the most direct or definitive diagnostic step in this highly symptomatic patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the rectum and sigmoid colon. Although many colorectal cancers are located in this distal segment, this procedure does not evaluate the transverse or right side of the colon. A negative flexible sigmoidoscopy would not rule out a more proximal malignancy, which is a significant possibility in a patient with iron deficiency anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Colonoscopy is the gold standard and most appropriate next step in highly suspected colorectal malignancy because it allows for direct visualization of the entire colonic mucosa, from the rectum to the cecum. Most importantly, it permits biopsy of any suspicious lesions for a definitive histopathologic diagnosis. It can also detect and remove synchronous polyps, which may be present elsewhere in the colon. Given the high suspicion for malignancy, a complete evaluation of the colon is essential.

D) INCORRECT:

A fecal immunochemical test (FIT) is a stool-based screening test for asymptomatic, average-risk individuals to detect occult blood. This patient is already symptomatic with known rectal bleeding and a positive guaiac test. An FIT would be redundant and would not provide any new diagnostic information, such as the location or nature of the bleeding source. A diagnostic procedure is required, not another screening test.

E) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker that can be elevated in colorectal cancer. However, it has low sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis, as it can be normal in early-stage disease and elevated in other malignancies or benign conditions such as smoking or inflammatory bowel disease. Its primary clinical use is for monitoring disease recurrence after treatment or assessing prognosis in patients with a known cancer diagnosis, not for establishing the initial diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's age, change in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, and iron deficiency anemia are alarm features that are highly suspicious for colorectal cancer.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man comes for a routine visit. He has no major health complaints and reports no change in bowel habits or rectal bleeding. He exercises regularly, has never smoked, and drinks alcohol occasionally. His father was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 72. There is no family history of other malignancies. He has never undergone screening procedures. Vital signs and physical examination are normal. Laboratory tests show normal complete blood count and basic metabolic panel.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient’s colorectal cancer screening?

choices.text: Routine annual fecal immunochemical testing at age 50

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Current guidelines recommend starting colorectal cancer screening at age 45 for average-risk individuals due to rising rates of early-onset colorectal cancer. The patient's father was diagnosed at age 72, which does not necessitate earlier screening. Colonoscopy is the gold standard for detecting early neoplastic changes, and starting at age 45 aligns with evidence-based practices for effective prevention and early intervention.

Key learning point: The recommended age to begin screening for colorectal cancer in average-risk individuals is 45 years old, according to the latest guidelines from major gastroenterology associations.

B) INCORRECT:

Screening at age 40 is recommended if a first-degree relative was diagnosed with colorectal cancer before age 60 or if there are one or more affected relatives. The patient's father was diagnosed at age 72, which does not meet these criteria, so the patient is considered average risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Fecal immunochemical testing (FIT) is a noninvasive screening option for average-risk individuals. However, current guidelines recommend starting colorectal cancer screening at age 45, not 50, for average-risk individuals, to allow for earlier detection.

D) INCORRECT:

Previous guidelines recommended starting screening at age 50 for average-risk individuals. However, updated guidelines now recommend starting at age 45 due to increased early-onset colorectal cancer rates. The patient's family history does not elevate his risk beyond average.
